The Tradition of Gajak

Gajak, often referred to as “til gud,” is a quintessential sweet treat that finds its origins deeply rooted in Indian traditions. This delicious confection is primarily made from two key ingredients: sesame seeds and jaggery. The art of making gajak is a time-honored tradition, passed down through generations. The ingredients are carefully roasted, mixed, and pressed into thin, sweet slabs that are cut into various shapes and sizes.

The combination of the nutty flavor of sesame seeds and the rich sweetness of jaggery results in a uniquely satisfying and flavorful treat. Gajak is often enjoyed during Makar Sankranti, Lohri, and other festivals that mark the harvest season. Its consumption is not limited to festivals alone; gajak is a beloved snack enjoyed year-round.
